results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 21]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film captures the Rankine/Woottons holidaying at Gosford, NSW coast.

Selected highlights list:

(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:00:05:00 up to this point, footage of a train travelling over a causeway from the mainland which can be identified as the Gosford area on the NSW coast.

00:00:06:00 - 00:00:18:00 panoramic footage being filmed from a vantage point above and where we see the Wootton family relaxed and on holidays as illustrated by their innovative footwear for the time: rubber thongs which were first produced in Australia by Dunlop in 1959.

00:00:19:00 to 00:00:44:00 footage of the bays and the town (presumably Gosford).

00:00:45:00 a prolonged shot of the three Wootton children looking more grown up and confident in front of the camera.

00:01:02:00 the family gather around what is likely to be a metal map on a pedestal for tourists.

00:01:45:00 footage is taken from a higher vantage point again at and includes a shot of fellow tourists at 00:01:52:00.

00:01:55:00 ‘Ploddy the Dinosaur’ (erected 1963) at the Australian Reptile Museum and Sanctuary at Gosford where we see snakes, lizards and other species in enclosures.

00:02:42:00 the family feeding tame kangaroos and cockatoos.
.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was our first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This collection of silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 4 shows the arrival and reception of the royal couple at Essendon Airport and their first progress through Melbourne.

Detailed Description Reel 4:

Opens with footage of arrival and reception at Melbourne Airport (Essendon). Official reception party greets the couple at exit from plane. 00:00:15:00 Party and crowd stand at attention for National Anthem. 00:00:32:00 Military salutes and review of troops. 00:01:10:00 Queen greets airplane crew, then full reception party. 00:02:35:00 Motorcade begins leaving Airport. 00:03:41:00 exterior shot of Essendon Town Hall with decorations and crowd followed by motorcade moving through streets. 00:04:01:0 - 00:04:41:00 reception at Essendon Town Hall entrance. 00:04:42:00 motorcade drives on, with shots of cheering crowds lining streets, shot from moving car. 00:05:35:00 arrival at Victorian State Parliament and shots of cheering crowds. 00:06:33:00 Queen and Duke pause halfway up Parliament House steps, flanked by Victorian Parliamentary Mace and Black Rod, who then precede them into the Parliament building. The camera then pans up the building to show the royal coat-of-arms and Royal Standard adorning the top. 00:06:59:00 artillery salute fired in Domain. 00:07:18:00 Queen and Duke exit building. 00:07:40:00 on return to their car the Queen and Duke are again flanked by the Victorian Parliamentary Mace and Black Rod. 00:08:00:00 car moves off, and is then filmed driving through Melbourne CBD through streets lined with cheering and flag-waving crowds. 00:08:35:00 exterior shot of Melbourne Town Hall.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel captures several rugby games in 1974 between Geelong Grammar School, Xavier College, Melbourne Grammar School and Scotch College.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 22]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 22 contains further footage of the royal visit to Mildura.

Detailed Description Reel 22:

Opens with motorcade driving through streets of unnamed town (probably Mildura), then scene shifts to airfield (again probably Mildura), surrounded by flag-waving crowds, with motorcade driving in. Officials mingle, and we see the “royal” in close-up. 00:02:21:00 the scene briefly shifts to Mildura weir, then an orchard (or vineyard) under irrigation. 00:02:37:00 back to the airfield, and more footage of the motorcade driving through streets. We then see a series of disconnected footage containing the royal couple waving to crowds from open car, in park and from a dais. 00:04:55:00 Crowd scenes of children at the park, including a parade carrying a “Mildura Legacy” banner. 00:05:40:00 we see a continuation of footage from previous Reels 20 & 21, of the Queen and Duke visiting a private property to observe the grape harvest. This is mixed up with scenes of Mildura streets and street decorations, scenes showing the “floral carpet” and grape decorations on the dais setup for the visit, and footage of people waiting for, waving at, and meeting the Queen and Duke.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This is a composite film of Hayes family life across the generations to include the grandchildren. The first segment is titled, ‘The Animals’ and features the family pets including dogs, calves, cows and the audacious cockatoo named Ticka, at home in suburban Heathmont in Melbourne’s outer east.

There are travel scenes of Narracan East, King River and the ‘Astor’ motel at Albury where Charles takes some dramatic footage of the Hume Weir. The family were keen tennis players and visited Albury at Easter so likely took part in the Albury Tennis Association competitions.

As well are some beach scenes at Point Leo, Golden Beach and Frankston where we see one of the dogs up to its neck in sand and some great examples of sixties bathing suits and sun hats.

The filmmaker shows some of the great cars at the time so that we see examples of 1960s and 1970s models. A brief segment from the Moomba Festival in Melbourne shows the ‘Frankston by the Sea’ song lyrics on one of the floats at the time.

Charles also shows the family’s involvement in tennis, trying out an early model Cortina car, and celebrating ‘Elinor’s 21st’ in white gloves and evening gowns and a display of the presents.

A particular feature of the film is the footage of ‘Southgate Fountain’ public art work by Robin Boyd (now demolished to make way for the redevelopment of Southgate on Melbourne’s Yarra river).

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:

00:06:24:00 Olwyn and Elenor in matching dresses, likely to be home made
00:06:57:00 title card ‘Narracan East’.

00:10:10:00 small boy, likely to be one of the filmmakers grandsons, kicking a large coloured ball in the backyard

00:11:13:00 caravan and Falcon station wagon

00:19:58:00 ‘Astor’ Motel/Hotel

results.description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993). The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This is a composite film of Hayes family life across the generations to include the grandchildren. The first segment is titled, ‘The Animals’ and features the family pets including dogs, calves, cows and the audacious cockatoo named Ticka, at home in suburban Heathmont in Melbourne’s outer east.

There are travel scenes of Narracan East, King River and the ‘Astor’ motel at Albury where Charles takes some dramatic footage of the Hume Weir. The family were keen tennis players and visited Albury at Easter so likely took part in the Albury Tennis Association competitions.

As well are some beach scenes at Point Leo, Golden Beach and Frankston where we see one of the dogs up to its neck in sand and some great examples of sixties bathing suits and sun hats.

The filmmaker shows some of the great cars at the time so that we see examples of 1960s and 1970s models. A brief segment from the Moomba Festival in Melbourne shows the ‘Frankston by the Sea’ song lyrics on one of the floats at the time.

Charles also shows the family’s involvement in tennis, trying out an early model Cortina car, and celebrating ‘Elinor’s 21st’ in white gloves and evening gowns and a display of the presents.

A particular feature of the film is the footage of ‘Southgate Fountain’ public art work by Robin Boyd (now demolished to make way for the redevelopment of Southgate on Melbourne’s Yarra river).

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 122]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This reel shows the family at the New South Wales coastal town of Eden, in 1938.

Opens with shots of small, masted boats in harbour (at Eden, New South Wales). One of the boats – with four men in it – is moving out of harbour under engine power.

This film was originally made using 16mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:29:00 a pier, with vehicular rails running along it and a small two-chimneyed ship moored alongside. A small masted vessel is being prepared for launching
00:00:43:00 close-up of a man striding through the camera’s field of vision, then the camera pans slowly over the sea and coastal landscape
00:01:28:00 a bush-fringed road, with a parked car and a man sitting nearby (with back to camera). The camera lingers on the surrounding bush and hills, with the sea visible in the background. This sequence appears to be shot from a vantage point further inland than the earlier coastal scenes
00:01:57:00 two people are standing at the base of a tall building; the camera pans up the structure to show the ‘battlements’ at its top. This is ‘Boyd’s Tower’, a 23 metre structure built in 1847 by the ex-Scottish entrepreneur Ben Boyd, intended as a lighthouse, but never commissioned.
00:02:20:00 entire tower photographed from a slight distance; the full structure can be seen above the surrounding bush
00:02:37:00 same man who appeared earlier in the footage and a woman wearing riding jodhpurs are standing on a rise overlooking the water as the camera pans past them across the scene of bush and sea
00:03:06:00 same man and woman – accompanied by an older woman – are strolling through a park or garden above the coast, looking away from the camera. A dog is frolicking around them, and a horse is grazing nearby.
00:03:24:0 same man walking along a rise, looking away from the camera at the sea and headlands below him. The camera tracks him as he walks further away from it, looking back over his shoulder occasionally.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

A highlight of Reel 12 is the footage of a garden party held at Government House; this Reel also includes further footage of Flinders Naval Depot (now HMAS Cerberus).

Detailed Description Reel 12:

Begins with continuation of Flinders Naval Depot visit by Duke (seen in Reel 11), with various parades and marches of naval personnel past dais where the Duke stands. 00:01:22:00 formation flyover. 00:01:30:00 Duke driven to another area and reviews what appear to be naval officers in training. More footage of naval personnel, marching, saluting, and presenting arms. 00:04:08:00 Duke re-boards train which moves off. 00:04:40:00 Title “Combined Women’s Organisations Luncheon”, followed by close-ups of women attendees dressed in their best. 00:05:05:00 crowd of flag-waving children holding banner “Melbourne Orphanage greets The Queen”. It is clearly a hot day - members of the crowd are holding sun-shades and covering their heads. 00:05:40:00 the Queen arrives. 00:06:02:00 to 00:06:06:00 a couple of children in the crowd can be seen holding “box brownie” cameras, keenly waiting to photograph the Queen. 00:06:27:00 Title “Garden Party at Government House”, followed by shots of guests arriving for the garden party. Wonderful shots of fashions and hats. Footage of guests strolling in gardens, with Government House building behind. Queen and Duke exit the building at 00:07:17:00 and walk towards crowd on grass. Footage of the crowd of guests in the garden is shot from a vantage point high in the building. Queen greets and talks with some of the guests, then enters a garden marquee. The Reel finishes with shot of Royal Standard flying over Government House.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 33]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film introduces the third Wootton child. Of particular note are the examples of hand made and hand knitted clothing worn by the children.

Selected highlights list:
(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:14:00:00 introduction of a third child to the Wootton family, with the three children sitting in the garden on the outdoor cane chairs very typical of the era; the older two children are showing their growing confidence in front of the camera.

00:02:11:00 we see a shot of the family in formal clothes , typical of the ‘Sunday best’ way of dressing and posing for photographs at the time.

00:02:40:00 to 00:02:59:00 shows the now toddler’s first steps to confident running around the lawn.
results.title_for_label: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 33]
results.description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film introduces the third Wootton child. Of particular note are the examples of hand made and hand knitted clothing worn by the children.

Selected highlights list:
(No title)
00:00:00:00 to 00:14:00:00 introduction of a third child to the Wootton family, with the three children sitting in the garden on the outdoor cane chairs very typical of the era; the older two children are showing their growing confidence in front of the camera.

00:02:11:00 we see a shot of the family in formal clothes , typical of the ‘Sunday best’ way of dressing and posing for photographs at the time.

00:02:40:00 to 00:02:59:00 shows the now toddler’s first steps to confident running around the lawn.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 36]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows some Geelong Grammar rugby games over June and July, 1972.

This film was originally made using Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Gadsden Family Home Movie Collection: Reel 168]
results.brief_description:
The Gadsden Company has a long and proud history of manufacture, dating back to its foundation by Jabez Gadsden in 1879. The company pioneered tinplate printing in Australia, and produced the first printed can the country had seen. By 1936 the company had twelve factories spread throughout Australia and New Zealand.

The company’s success allowed two generations of Gadsden family men – Stanley Gadsden and his son Ronald – to pursue their interest in amateur filmmaking (a relatively expensive hobby for the time). The two cameramen captured the family’s children, homes, many of its major events and holidays on film.

A collection of the films made by these Gadsden family photographers has been donated to ACMI by Chris Gadsden (Ronald’s son). The films comprise a fascinating assortment of imagery that provides a window into bygone days and customs.

This film shows downhill, cross-country and slalom skiing at Mt Buller, Victoria, including the Women’s National Ski Competition in August 1947 and 1948 (according to notes on the donated original film can). There are good views including a horse drawn sled, snow fashion of the era and a ski lodge.

This film was originally made using 16mm film. Some of the footage is overexposed.

Selected highlights list
00:00:02:00 downhill ski race, various competitors filmed from a fixed camera position
00:02:40:00 views of snowed covered mountains
00:02:50:00 skiers in distance going downhill, possible slalom
00:03:46:00 better footage of downhill slalom
00:04:36:00 skiers walking uphill wearing skis, views of mountain and ski lodge
00:04:49:00 skiers walking uphill wearing skis
00:04:58:00 good footage of horse drawn sled
00:05:06:00 skiers walking wearing skis
00:06:50:00 group cross country skiing with sled
00:06:58:00 man strapped to sled (possibly injured or practising)
00:07:08:00 man gets off sled at ski lodge amid group of skiers
00:07:17:00 close up views of skiers at lodge showing fashions of the era
00:07:35:00 people riding horse drawn sled
00:07:44:00 downhill skiing
00:08:32:00 dining room in ski lodge full of diners (waitress in uniform)
00:09:03:00 mountain views
00:09:40:00 horse riding
00:10:38:00 man standing by car loaded with skis
